Q: Group results from a CodeIgniter query and create a subarray of values per group A:

Because I don't know if it is possible for user values to contain a comma (or any othe arbitrarily selected delimiter), I'll avoid using GROUP_CONCAT() to consolidate user values into a delimited string per group.

Instead, a JSON encoded string will be more stable (minimum MySQL8 or higher). You'll just need to call PHP's json_decode() on the users column value of each row.

Just in case vgro_name values are not guaranteed to be unique per vgro_id, group by and select both of those columns to ensure accurate grouping.

The JSON data will not be sorted, so if that is necessary, then sort after decoding.

public function getUsersByGroup(): array
{
    return $this->db
        ->select('g.vgro_id,g.vgro_name,JSON_ARRAYAGG(u.vusr_user) users')
        ->join('vts_user_by_group b', 'b.vubg_vgro_id = g.vgro_id')
        ->join('vts_users u', 'b.vubg_vusr_id = u.vusr_id')
        ->group_by('g.vgro_id,g.vgro_name')
        ->get('vts_groups g')
        ->result();
}

Result set:

vgro_id vgro_name users
1 GROUP1 ["john", "alice"]
2 GROUP2 ["mark"]

Q: How to code defaults for categorical arguments to functions in R? A:

Like @Steve says, the way the function is defined makes of "a" the default. Try my_function <- function(x=0, switch=c("a", "b", "c")) {sw <- match.arg(switch);sw} and call my_function() to see what match.arg catches. match.arg has the benefit of throwing an error if you pass an invalid value for switch. For instance, my_function(switch = "d")

Q: How to correctly establish connection with active directory via LDAP in Golang A:

  • Please temporarily enable Schannel logging on the domain controller Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/developer/webapps/iis/health-diagnostic-performance/enable-schannel-event-logging and set logging level = 7. This will enable detailed events from your LDAP over TLS connection to be observed in Event Viewer - System logs.

  • Temporarily enable CAPI2 event logs for the following scenarios:

On the domain controller that your LDAP code connects to when your code runs

If possible, on a Windows client using ldp.exe, you can connect to the domain controller over LDAP(s): First connect to the FQDN of the domain controller, then bind using several authentication options on the ldp.exe utility GUI.

On the domain controller, run ldp.exe connect to the domain controller over LDAP(s): First connect to the FQDN of the domain controller, then bind using several authentication options on the ldp.exe utility GUI.

Then check CAPI2 logs on the client and server to see which TLS certificate is retrieved during LDAP(s) connections to the domain controller.

Taking into account the ref. link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/windows-server/active-directory/ldap-over-ssl-connection-issues?source=recommendations

Check the server certificate that is used as the LDAP over TLS connection meets the criteria in the above link. The server LDAP certificate that is presented during LDAP over TLS connections can be verified using step 3.

If you have a client certificate during the client-to-LDAP server (DC) LDAP(s) connection, please check the ref link above. Your code will dictate whether the end user client pc directly connects to the LDAP server or only the application servers connect to the domain controller. Each case will treat client certificate differently.

Please check the link https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/windows-server/active-directory/ldap-session-security-settings-requirements-adv190023:

If your domain controller forces the following settings, the classes and methods in your code have to set the same options during LDAP connections:

LDAPServerIntegrity : LDAP Signing requirement

LdapEnforceChannelBinding: LDAP Channel Binding Token (CBT Token) requirement (Extended Protection). CBT is used during TLS connections in order to prevent man-in-the-middle attacks.

In the Schannel logs you will find such Schannel events revealing CBTs of the TLS connections:

Protocol Version: TLS 1.3

CipherSuite: 0x1302

Key Exchange : 384 bit

Binding identifier: 0x1ac418614b0 ------> (CBT identifier)

Target Name:domain.com

Local certificate subject name:

Remote certificate subject name: C=xx,O=oo,....

Please check the TLS versions supported and cipher sets on both Linux/Windows side which attempts LDAP over TLS connections and the domain controller:

For Windows OS, you may see https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/secauthn/protocols-in-tls-ssl--schannel-ssp- to check which TLS versions are supported on different OS versions.

You may also check the domain controller registry branch for additional TLS version restrictions - if exists -
'HKLM SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SCHANNEL\Protocols'
